item.title: Steventon, Hampshire, Census Returns 1851-1901
item.description:
Steventon was a small agricultural village mainly on the chalk of the Hampshire downs. The farming was mixed with predominantly corn and sheep but in the late 19th century cattle were increasingly raised and the importance of sheep declined slightly. After 1881 there was a resident lord of the manor, before that the village was dominated by the rector and the tenant of the Manor farm. Population increased slowly during this period.

There was no station in Steventon but the London to Southampton line crossed the parish and some villagers worked on the railway.
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Steventon Probate Material, 1681-1700
item.description:
The two wills and three inventories reveal a sheep and corn farming community.

These transcriptions have been made from copies of original probate documents supplied by HRO and TNA.  Words have been modernized and punctuation added to make reading easier but names have been transcribed as written. Words in italics indicate omissions in the original document which have been added to make sense of the text. Words in square brackets indicate that they have been transcribed as seen but where the meaning is unclear. Basingstoke is described as being in the county of Southampton, the old name for Hampshire.

A glossary is attached of unusual words.

 

 

 

  • Elinor Smith, widow, 1681 (Will and inventory)
  • Thomas Small, yeoman, 1687 (Inventory)
  • Richard Passiant/Passion, yeoman, 1689 (Will and inventory)
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Steventon Probate Material, 1661-80
item.description:
This period is interesting as it contains the inventories of two of the Orpwood family who were the rectors of Steventon in this period.

These transcriptions have been made from copies of original probate documents supplied by HRO and TNA.  Words have been modernized and punctuation added to make reading easier but names have been transcribed as written. Words in italics indicate omissions in the original document which have been added to make sense of the text. Words in square brackets indicate that they have been transcribed as seen but where the meaning is unclear. Basingstoke is described as being in the county of Southampton, the old name for Hampshire.

A glossary is attached of unusual words.

 

 

 

  • Charles Covey, husbandman, 1661 (Will and inventory)
  • Joanne Orpwood alias Harmar, 1670 (Inventory)
  • John Orpewood, rector, 1671 (Inventory)
  • William Passiant/Passion, yeoman, 1676 (Will and inventory)
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Steventon Probate Material, 1641-60
item.description:
Woodruff’s will from just before the outbreak of the English civil war is interesting for its indication of a local commercial woollen industry.

These transcriptions have been made from copies of original probate documents supplied by HRO and TNA.  Words have been modernized and punctuation added to make reading easier but names have been transcribed as written. Words in italics indicate omissions in the original document which have been added to make sense of the text. Words in square brackets indicate that they have been transcribed as seen but where the meaning is unclear. Basingstoke is described as being in the county of Southampton, the old name for Hampshire.

A glossary is attached of unusual words.

 

 

 

  • Richard Wodrofe, yeoman, 1641(Will and inventory)
  • John Cotterell, 1648 (Inventory)

item.title: Steventon Probate Material, 1621-40
item.description:
The will and four surviving inventories indicate a mixed farming economy of crops, sheep and cattle.

These transcriptions have been made from copies of original probate documents supplied by HRO and TNA.  Words have been modernized and punctuation added to make reading easier but names have been transcribed as written. Words in italics indicate omissions in the original document which have been added to make sense of the text. Words in square brackets indicate that they have been transcribed as seen but where the meaning is unclear. Basingstoke is described as being in the county of Southampton, the old name for Hampshire.

A glossary is attached of unusual words.

 

 

 

  • Joanne Crooke, widow, 1625 (Inventory and bond)
  • Richard Perrin, yeoman, 1626 (Will and inventory)
  • John Hunt, yeoman, 1630 (Inventory and bond)
  • John Worsham, 1640 (Will and inventory)
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Steventon probate material, 1601-20
item.description:
Two wills and four inventories survive for this period, of which the Ansell and Crook families were copyholders of the manor of Steventon. Crook was also a freeholder with 60 acres. The farming is mixed with mainly sheep and corn but Crook also possessed 10 cows and seven bullocks.

These transcriptions have been made from copies of original probate documents supplied by HRO and TNA.  Words have been modernized and punctuation added to make reading easier but names have been transcribed as written. Words in italics indicate omissions in the original document which have been added to make sense of the text. Words in square brackets indicate that they have been transcribed as seen but where the meaning is unclear. Basingstoke is described as being in the county of Southampton, the old name for Hampshire.

A glossary is attached of unusual words.

 

 

  • Robert Greenway/Greenwaie, 1608 (Inventory)
  • Elizabeth Ansell,  widow,1613 (Inventory and bond)
  • John Crooke, senior, yeoman (Will and inventory)
  • William Rabbnet, 1617 (Will and inventory)
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Steventon Probate Material, 1581-1600
item.description:
William Lover was a substantial freeholder with 60 acres. The three inventories reflect mixed farming of mainly sheep with wheat and barley.

These transcriptions have been made from copies of original probate documents supplied by HRO and TNA.  Words have been modernized and punctuation added to make reading easier but names have been transcribed as written. Words in italics indicate omissions in the original document which have been added to make sense of the text. Words in square brackets indicate that they have been transcribed as seen but where the meaning is unclear. Basingstoke is described as being in the county of Southampton, the old name for Hampshire.

A glossary is attached of unusual words.

 

 

 

  • Edward Hellier, 1591 (Will and inventory)
  • William Lover, 1591 (Will and inventory)
  • Ingram Upton, husbandman, 1594 (Will and inventory)

The three surviving wills and inventories reflect a mixed farming community in which sheep and wheat dominated.

These transcriptions have been made from copies of original probate documents supplied by HRO and TNA.  Words have been modernized and punctuation added to make reading easier but names have been transcribed as written. item.title: Steventon Probate Material, 1541-60
item.description:
The three wills reflect Catholic practices of praying for the soul. William Morall had interests in seven parishes but the reason is not apparent.

These transcriptions have been made from copies of original probate documents supplied by HRO and TNA.  Words have been modernized and punctuation added to make reading easier but names have been transcribed as written. Words in italics indicate omissions in the original document which have been added to make sense of the text. Words in square brackets indicate that they have been transcribed as seen but where the meaning is unclear. Basingstoke is described as being in the county of Southampton, the old name for Hampshire.

A glossary is attached of unusual words.

 

 

 

  • William Morall, 1546 (Will)
  • Johanne Morall, 1546 (Will)
  • William Dunce, 1559 (Will and inventory)
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Steventon Probate Material, 1521-1540
item.description:
There is a suggestion of an epidemic disease in 1533 as only four wills survive for the 1530s, all of which are from July and August 1533  which indicate it may have been plague. Plague deaths usually peaked from July to October. The four who died were related. No parish records of burials exist for this period so this interpretation cannot be confirmed. See Social History.

The wills of the 1520s and the early 1530s precede the Reformation and display Catholic religious practices.

These transcriptions have been made from copies of original probate documents supplied by HRO and TNA.  Words have been modernized and punctuation added to make reading easier but names have been transcribed as written. Words in italics indicate omissions in the original document which have been added to make sense of the text. Words in square brackets indicate that they have been transcribed as seen but where the meaning is unclear. Basingstoke is described as being in the county of Southampton, the old name for Hampshire.

A glossary is attached of unusual words.

 

  • Christopher Denby, 1528 (Will)
  • Thomas Waite, 1533 (Will)
  • Annis Waite, 1533 (Will)
  • Geoffrey Smith/Smythe, 1533 (Will)
  • John Waite, 1533 (Will)
